docs.lead_paragraph: As Japan fumbles for ways to stabilize its wobbly banks, another potentially destabilizing crisis is brewing in the nation's life insurance industry, the world's largest, which has also been hurt by the weak stock market, record-low interest rates and the sour economy. Like the banks, the insurers hold huge amounts of stocks and bonds, and the collapse of one or more of them -- something analysts say is a distinct possibility -- could further rattle jittery investors. The potential for such a meltdown has risen as stock prices have fallen to near 19-year lows and left most insurers with losses in their portfolios.

headline.main: Sagging Stocks in Japan Put Life Insurers at Risk

docs.abstract: Sagging Japanese stock markets debilitate finances of country's life insurers, holders of huge amounts of stocks and bonds; banks, crippled by identical portfolios, have less available cash to purchase insurers' debts (M)
docs.snippet: As Japan fumbles for ways to stabilize its wobbly banks, another potentially destabilizing crisis is brewing in the nation's life insurance industry, the world's largest, which has also been hurt by the weak stock market, record-low interest rates...

docs.lead_paragraph: The number of Americans without health insurance rose to 41.2 million last year, an increase of 1.4 million, and small businesses accounted for much of the erosion in coverage, the Census Bureau said today. The proportion of the population without insurance also increased, to 14.6 percent in 2001, from 14.2 percent in 2000, the bureau said.

headline.main: After Decline, The Number Of Uninsured Rose in 2001

docs.abstract: Census Bureau reports number of Americans without health insurance rose to 41.2 million in 2001, increase of 1.4 million, and that small businesses accounted for much of erosion in coverage; proportion of population without insurance also increased, to 14.6 percent in 2001, from 14.2 percent in 2000; lawmakers and lobbyists sayincrease could propel health insurance back to forefront of national debate; even as need grows, federal government and states are lesss able to provide aid because revenues have shrunk in recession; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Blair Says He Is Confident Of U.N. Resolution on Iraq Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain expressed confidence of securing a United Nations resolution on Iraqi weapons. Mr. Blair refused to rule out acting along with the United States if the United Nations failed to endorse military action against Iraq. A1 Israel Withdraws Troops Israel withdrew from Yasir Arafat's compound in Ramallah, ending a 10-day siege of the Palestinian leader that had put the Israeli government in a diplomatic corner. Mr. Arafat emerged to celebrate what his aides called a triumph, but he called on Palestinians to observe a truce with Israel. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Whether the comparison was Sontag's or the senator's, the assertion that the family of a 19-year-old in a serious car accident would not face the predicament of forgoing treatment or being crushed by debt is, unfortunately, dead wrong. Our 19-year-old son was catastrophically injured in a high-speed head-on collision when a van crossed the center line. We learned that families of a person with a severe head injury have options much like the ones the Domenicis describe. Brain injury creates a wide array of physical, mental and emotional impairments. Care for its mental and emotional consequences is limited, like care for mental illness. And although physically devastating injuries are covered, cost-containment pressures began almost immediately for us to ''give up'' on our son. Even though he made a strong recovery, health-insurance policies have painfully little coverage for the many rehab therapies needed for decades, if not for life. Marjorie M. Shultz Richmond, Calif.
docs.abstract: Marjorie M Shultz letter disputes assertion in Deborah Sontag's September 15 article that families of those involved in serious car accidents do not face same predicaments as those whose members are mentally ill

docs.lead_paragraph: I commend Senator Pete Domenici's efforts to pass legislation enforcing parity in insurance coverage for physical and mental health, but I was disappointed that his wife apparently prevented the reporter from talking directly to their daughter, Clare, claiming that she was ''simply too 'wobbly' right now'' (Deborah Sontag, Sept. 15). Increased visibility and integration into society are the most effective ways to end discrimination against people living with mental illnesses, or for that matter, with any stigmatized physical condition. Clare is not a child; she is a 40-year-old woman who knows better than anyone else how her 20-year struggle with schizophrenia has affected her emotionally, physically and financially. It's one thing if she was unwilling to talk to the reporter because she wanted to protect her privacy or felt uncomfortable for other reasons. But it's patronizing for her parents to continue to make such decisions for her, even if their reasons are based on the very best of intentions. Jeff Hoover Brooklyn
docs.abstract: Jeff Hoover letter on Deborah Sontag's September 15 article holds Sen Peter Dominici's daughter Clare, who is schizophrenic, should decide for herself whether she wants to talk with reporters

docs.lead_paragraph: Hilary Gardner, the daughter of Susan and G. Peabody Gardner Jr. of Dedham, Mass., was married yesterday to David Hutcheson McDonald, the son of Nancy P. Landt and John H. McDonald, both of Atlanta. The Rev. Dr. Peter J. Gomes, who is the Plummer professor of Christian morals at Harvard University, performed an Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's paternal grandparents, Tatiana and George Peabody Gardner, in Prides Crossing, Mass. Mrs. McDonald, 26, was until May an associate at Elizabeth K. Allen Inc., event planners in New York. She graduated from the University of Montana. Her father is a fund-raising officer at Harvard.

docs.lead_paragraph: While I applaud the efforts of Domenici and colleagues 2/3 I find it worrisome that they are motivated to legislate by personal experience. Lawmakers are disproportionately affluent, middle-aged white men who may not share the concerns important to the vast majority of their constituents. Ideally they would have the insight, compassion and sensitivity to perceive problems that afflict the common man without requiring a personal brush with tragedy to galvanize their legislative zeal. There are a lot of problems out there that don't affect these guys directly. David G. Rabkin, M.D. New York
docs.abstract: Dr David G Rabkin letter on Deborah Sontag's September 15 article praises insurance reforms sought by Sen Pete Domenici and colleagues but holds personal experience should not be motivating factor

docs.lead_paragraph: Luz Portillo, who takes home $155 a week from her part-time job as a janitor, proudly wears an oversized purple shirt that declares, ''Standing Up for the American Dream.'' For Ms. Portillo, a 27-year-old immigrant from El Salvador, the American dream involves, at a minimum, obtaining a full-time job and health insurance for herself and her two young daughters.

headline.main: Janitors in the Boston Area Are Threatening to Strike

docs.abstract: Boston-area janitors are threatening to strike on Sept 30; janitors are seeking higher wages, health insurance, full-time jobs and respect for largely invisible, largely immigrant work force; union is seeking more full-tme jobs; less than 25 percent of nearly 11,000 unionized workers work full time, and since only full-time cleaners receive health insurance, more than 75 percent of workers do not receive health coverage from their jobs; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE American welfare state was supposed to be dead, victim of the free-market economy and its success in creating a job for anybody who wanted one. While European countries maintained huge social-service programs and paid for them with high unemployment, the United States sharply curtailed its best-known welfare program in the mid-1990's and the jobless rate just kept dropping. Even today, two years into an economic slump, the labor market appears healthier than it was for most of the last three decades.

headline.main: The Nation: Help Wanted; Out of a Job and No Longer Looking

docs.abstract: American labor market appears healthier than it was for most of last three decades, but current downturn is beginning to expose uncomfortable truth: American economy looks more like Europe's than most people ever imagined during triumphal 1990's; millions of people, particularly men, have dropped out of labor force over last decade, apparently unable to find work that pays near what they once earned in blue-collar jobs that have since moved to lower-wage countries; because they are not actively looking for work, they are not counted in jobless rate; surprising and growing number of them instead depend on government check to get by; photos; graph (M)
